Hello David,

My knowledge of the Python is almost zero but as I could unde=
rstand 
you try to calculate the burning velocity of the methane/air flame =
at 
equivalence ratio of 1.3 with GRI-Mech 3.0 chemical mechanism. At 
this=
 equivalence ratio the Cantera code should work seamlessly. At 
least I cou=
ld calculate free burning velocities of the CH4/Air flames 
using only C++ =
routines from Cantera for Phi <=3D 1.6. Unfortunately, I 
don't understand =
Python scripts. There are a few remarks, though. 
1.	In calculations for in=
itial guess a coarse grid should be 
used, 6 grid points is more than enoug=
h.
2.	Tolerances and other parameters for the TwoPnt solver are 
different =
than those of mine. I used the following values:
RTolSS =3D 1e-5           =
                          ; Relative 
tolerance for steady state solution
A=
TolSS =3D 1e-010                                   ; Absolute 
tolerance fo=
r steady state  solution
RTolTS =3D 0.0001                                 =
  ; Relative tolerance
	for time step solution
ATolTS =3D 1e-005           =
                        ; Relative 
tolerance for time step solution
MaxTim=
eStep =3D 0.0001                              ; maximal time step 
NumberSt=
eps =3D "1, 2, 5, 20, 50"                   ; Number of steps 
for time run=
s
TimeStep =3D 1e-006                                 ; initial time step
T=
imeStepfactor =3D 0.45                             ; multiplication 
factor=
 after failure in time integration
JacobianAge =3D 20                      =
            ; maximal number of 
iterations before evaluation of jacobian  =
   

3. Initial speed should be not very high and certainly less then the 
=
free burning velocity. I use usually 5 cm/s.  

Hope this helps. 
Best rega=
rds,  Anatoli
